writing_prompt: A master art forger turned FBI consultant finds himself at a crossroads when his old partner proposes a heist that feels... wrong. For the first time, he hesitates—has he really changed, or is he just fooling himself?
story:
Neal Caffrey leaned back in his chair, staring at the ceiling of his office in the FBI’s White Collar Division. It was ironic, really. Here he was, a master art forger turned consultant, working with the same institution that had once hunted him. The transition had been anything but smooth, filled with moments of doubt and the constant battle between his old instincts and this new path he was trying to carve out for himself.

His life had been a whirlwind of high-stakes cons, glamorous parties, and the thrill of outsmarting the best. But now, his days were spent in an office, poring over case files and using his expertise to catch others like his former self. It was rewarding, in its own way, but there were times he missed the rush of the con.

The knock on his door pulled him from his reverie. Peter Burke, his handler and now friend, stepped in, a file in hand. "Neal, got a minute?"

"Sure, Peter. What’s up?" Neal sat up straight, pushing his musings aside.

Peter handed him the file. "Take a look at this. It’s a proposal from someone you might remember."

Neal opened the file and his heart skipped a beat. The name on the first page was one he hadn’t seen in years—Vincent Adler, his old partner in crime. The man who had taught him everything about the art world and forgery.

"He’s proposing a heist," Peter said, watching Neal’s reaction closely. "And he wants you in on it."

Neal’s mind raced. Adler had always been a step ahead, always had a plan. But this… this felt different. He flipped through the pages, the details of the heist laid out meticulously. It was brilliant, but there was something off, something that made Neal’s stomach churn.

"Why would he come to me with this?" Neal asked, more to himself than to Peter.

"I don’t know," Peter admitted. "But I need to know where you stand. This is a big deal, Neal. If you’re even thinking about going back…"

Neal shook his head. "I’m not. It’s just… Adler. He’s not someone who does things without a reason."

Peter nodded. "I trust you, Neal. But I need you to be sure about this. If you’re in, you’re in. If you’re out, I need you to be all the way out."

Neal closed the file, the weight of Peter’s words sinking in. "Give me some time to think about it."

Peter left, and Neal sat in silence, the file still in his hands. The heist was perfect, the kind of job he would have jumped at without a second thought in his past life. But now, there was more at stake. His position at the FBI, his relationship with Peter, the trust he’d built—it all hung in the balance.

He spent the next few days in a state of constant turmoil. He would go from being certain he had to reject the proposal to wondering if he was fooling himself about having changed. The temptation was real. The allure of the heist, the thrill of the chase—it was all so familiar, so enticing.

But then he thought of Peter. The man had believed in him when no one else did. He had given him a chance to prove he could be more than just a con artist. He had trusted him, and Neal didn’t want to betray that trust.

Finally, the day came when he had to make his decision. He walked into Peter’s office, the file clutched in his hand.

"Peter, I’ve made up my mind."

Peter looked up from his desk, his expression unreadable. "And?"

Neal took a deep breath. "I’m out. I can’t go back to that life. Not now, not ever."

For a moment, Peter said nothing. Then, he smiled, a genuine smile that reached his eyes. "I’m glad to hear that, Neal. I knew you’d make the right choice."

Neal felt a weight lift off his shoulders. It was the right choice. The hard choice. But it was his choice.

That evening, as he walked through the streets of New York, he felt a sense of peace he hadn’t felt in a long time. He had changed. He wasn’t just fooling himself. He had chosen the harder path, but it was the path that felt right.

He glanced back at the FBI building, its lights a beacon in the night. He knew there would be more temptations, more moments of doubt. But he also knew he had people who believed in him, and that made all the difference.

He was Neal Caffrey, former art forger turned FBI consultant. And for the first time, he was truly free.

writing_prompt: When Crowley ran into Dean Winchester after years apart, he never expected it to lead to late-night confessions, stolen kisses, and a life tangled with federal agents and family barbecues. But some things, it seems, are worth rewriting the plan for.
story:
Crowley had always prided himself on being one step ahead. In the world of demons, angels, and hunters, it was a necessity, not a luxury. Yet, as he stood in the dimly lit bar nursing a glass of top-shelf whiskey, he reflected on how one man had always managed to throw his meticulously laid plans into disarray—Dean Winchester.

It had been years since their paths had last crossed. Crowley had moved on, or so he told himself, diving deeper into the machinations of Hell. But something about that rugged hunter had always stayed with him, a persistent itch that no amount of scheming or double-crossing could scratch away.

Seeing Dean again had been a shock. Crowley had been on a routine reconnaissance mission, nothing more than a quick in-and-out to gather intel. But there Dean was, leaning against his sleek black Impala, eyes scanning the horizon as if he were waiting for something—or someone. Their eyes met, and in that instant, Crowley's carefully constructed world tilted on its axis.

"Well, if it isn't Squirrel," Crowley greeted, trying to mask the turmoil inside him with a smirk.

Dean's lips curled into a half-smile. "Crowley. Didn't expect to see you here."

"Nor I, you," Crowley admitted, stepping closer. "What brings you to this neck of the woods?"

Dean shrugged, the leather of his jacket creaking softly. "Just following a lead. You know how it is."

Crowley did know. He knew all too well the relentless pursuit of answers, the constant battle against the unknown. But now, standing so close to Dean, his mind was filled with questions of a different sort. Questions about what could have been, what might still be.

The night progressed in a blur of shared drinks and stolen glances. They talked about old times, battles fought side by side, and the scars they both bore. As the hours slipped away, the bar emptied, leaving just the two of them in the soft glow of the neon lights.

"Why did you leave?" Dean's voice was barely above a whisper, but it cut through the silence like a knife.

Crowley sighed, running a hand through his hair. "I thought it was for the best. For both of us."

"Bull," Dean shot back, eyes flashing with anger and something else—hurt. "You ran because you were scared."

"Maybe I was," Crowley conceded, his voice raw. "But can you blame me? We were on opposite sides, Dean. It was never meant to be."

"And now?" Dean asked, stepping closer, his breath warm against Crowley's skin. "What about now?"

Crowley didn't have an answer. Instead, he closed the distance between them, capturing Dean's lips in a desperate kiss. It was a kiss that spoke of years of longing, of missed opportunities and regrets. When they finally pulled apart, both were breathless, eyes locked in a silent understanding.

The next few weeks were a whirlwind. Crowley found himself entangled in Dean's world, navigating the complexities of federal agents and family barbecues. It was a far cry from the underworld he was used to, but somehow, it felt right. 

One evening, after a particularly tense encounter with a federal agent who had been sniffing too close to their trail, Crowley and Dean found themselves alone on the porch of Bobby's old house. The sun was setting, casting a warm glow over the yard where Sam was playing catch with his son.

"You ever think about just... stopping?" Dean asked, his voice soft as he watched his brother and nephew.

Crowley took a sip of his drink, considering the question. "Stopping what? The endless chase? The battles?"

"Yeah," Dean replied, turning to face him. "Just... living. You and me."

Crowley smiled, a genuine smile that felt foreign on his face. "I think about it all the time."

Dean reached out, taking Crowley's hand in his. "Then let's do it. Let's rewrite the plan."

And so they did. They faced the challenges together, from the relentless federal agents to the everyday struggles of blending their lives. But through it all, they found a new kind of strength in each other. The late-night confessions and stolen kisses became their anchors, grounding them in a world that seemed determined to pull them apart.

In the end, it wasn't the battles or the schemes that defined them. It was the quiet moments, the shared laughter and whispered promises. Crowley had never expected to find a home, least of all with a hunter. But as he stood there, hand in hand with Dean, watching the sun set over their new life, he realized that some things were indeed worth rewriting the plan for.

writing_prompt: A con artist turned FBI consultant accidentally finds himself defending proper legal procedures during a heated case discussion—much to the amusement of his by-the-book handler, who never lets him live it down.
story:
Neal Caffrey never thought he’d find himself here, sitting in a conference room at the FBI, a respectable consultant to the very organization that once hunted him. His past as a con artist seemed like a distant memory, though it always lingered in the back of his mind, a reminder of the path he’d taken to get here. Today, as he studied the evidence laid out before him, Neal couldn’t help but reflect on the irony of his situation.

He was examining a set of counterfeit bonds, the kind he would have forged flawlessly in his previous life. As he scrutinized the details, a realization struck him—a crucial insight that could crack the case wide open. Neal’s heart raced with anticipation as he prepared to share his findings with the team.

Agent Peter Burke, his handler and the man who’d finally caught him, entered the room with his typical air of authority. Peter’s eyes met Neal’s, and for a brief moment, there was an unspoken understanding between them. Neal had come a long way from the prison cell where Peter had first offered him the deal that changed his life.

“Alright, everyone, let’s hear what we’ve got,” Peter said, addressing the team.

Neal cleared his throat and began to speak. “I’ve been looking at the bonds, and I noticed something interesting. The forger used a technique that’s almost identical to one I used years ago. The key is in the watermark. It’s slightly off-center, which means it was likely done in a rush.”

Peter raised an eyebrow, clearly intrigued. “And how does that help us?”

“It means the forger made a mistake,” Neal explained, a hint of excitement in his voice. “We can trace the watermark to a specific printer. If we find the printer, we find the forger.”

The team nodded in agreement, impressed by Neal’s insight. However, the conversation quickly took a turn when Agent Jones brought up a potential shortcut to expedite the process.

“Why don’t we just bring in some suspects for questioning and see who cracks first?” Jones suggested.

Neal’s eyes widened, and before he could stop himself, he blurted out, “We can’t just haul people in without probable cause! That’s a violation of their rights.”

The room fell silent, and all eyes turned to Neal. Peter’s lips twitched, struggling to suppress a smile. The irony of Neal, a former con artist, defending legal procedures was not lost on him.

“Neal’s right,” Peter said, his voice laced with amusement. “We have to follow proper protocol. We can’t afford to have this case thrown out because we didn’t do things by the book.”

Jones chuckled and shook his head. “Never thought I’d see the day when Neal Caffrey would be lecturing us on legal procedures.”

Neal felt a flush of embarrassment but held his ground. “Look, I know it sounds strange coming from me, but I’ve learned a lot working here. The law matters, and if we want to catch this guy and make it stick, we have to do it the right way.”

Peter clapped Neal on the back, a proud smile on his face. “Spoken like a true consultant. Let’s get to work on tracing that watermark.”

As the team dispersed to their tasks, Peter lingered behind with Neal. “You know, I never thought I’d see the day.”

“What day?” Neal asked, though he had a feeling he knew where this was going.

“The day you’d be lecturing us on proper legal procedures,” Peter said with a grin. “You’ve come a long way, Neal.”

Neal shrugged, a small smile playing on his lips. “Guess you’re rubbing off on me, Peter.”

Peter’s expression softened, and there was a moment of genuine respect between them. “I’m glad to hear it. Now let’s go catch this forger.”

As they delved deeper into the case, Neal couldn’t help but feel a sense of pride. He had indeed come a long way from his days as a con artist. The thrill of the chase was still there, but now it was tempered with a newfound respect for the law and the people who upheld it.

By the end of the day, they had tracked down the printer and, subsequently, the forger. It was a satisfying conclusion to a challenging case, and Neal felt a sense of accomplishment that was different from the hollow victories of his past.

As they wrapped up, Peter turned to Neal and said, “You did good today. Keep this up, and you might just make a decent agent one day.”

Neal chuckled, shaking his head. “Let’s not get ahead of ourselves, Peter.”

But as they walked out of the office together, Neal couldn’t help but feel that, for the first time in his life, he was on the right side of the law. And maybe, just maybe, he was becoming the kind of man he’d always wanted to be.

writing_prompt: The starship is stranded, dead in space, with no apparent reason for the failure. As the clock ticks down and theories crumble, the chief engineer must uncover the truth before the crew's time runs out.
story:
Scotty stared at the lifeless console, his fingers hovering above the controls as if willing the ship to revive itself. The U.S.S. Enterprise, the pride of Starfleet, was stranded in the middle of nowhere, dead in space. It was a situation that defied all logic and reason, and it gnawed at him. The ship had always been his to understand and protect, and now it was as if it had turned its back on him.

"Chief Engineer's log, stardate 5483.6," he muttered, though the log recorder was as dead as the rest of the systems. "Enterprise is in total systems failure. No propulsion, no life support, no communication. The cause remains unknown. The crew's survival depends on finding the problem before our life support reserves run out."

His mind raced, tracing every possible failure point, every subsystem that could have gone wrong. It wasn't just his job; it was his responsibility, his life. He had to find the answer, and soon.

"Scotty." The familiar voice of Captain Kirk pulled him from his thoughts. Kirk's face was etched with concern, a rare sight for the usually unflappable captain. "Any progress?"

"None, sir." Scotty's frustration was palpable. "It's as if the ship just decided to take a nap and forgot to wake up. I've been through every diagnostic I can think of, but nothing's showing up."

Kirk nodded, his eyes reflecting the same worry that gnawed at Scotty. "Keep at it. We're counting on you."

As Kirk left, Scotty turned back to the console. He couldn't let the crew down. He wouldn't. He reached for his toolkit, feeling the comforting weight of his trusted instruments. There had to be something they were missing.

"Chief, I've got an idea," came the voice of Ensign Chekov, who had quietly approached. The young navigator had a knack for thinking outside the box, and Scotty was willing to try anything at this point.

"Let's hear it, lad," Scotty said, turning to face him.

"What if it's not a failure in the ship's systems at all? What if it's some kind of external interference?" Chekov suggested, his eyes alight with the possibility of a new angle.

Scotty's brow furrowed. It was a long shot, but given their situation, it was worth considering. "External interference... That would mean something's affecting the ship from outside. But what?"

"Radiation, perhaps? Or some kind of energy field we've never encountered before?" Chekov offered.

Scotty's mind whirled with the implications. "Alright, let's run a full spectrum analysis. If there's something out there, we'll find it."

Hours passed as Scotty and Chekov worked side by side, scanning for any hint of external interference. The ship's crew moved with a quiet efficiency, aware of the stakes but trusting in their chief engineer's abilities.

And then, a flicker. A tiny blip on the scanner, almost imperceptible.

"Hold on, I've got something," Chekov said, his voice tight with excitement.

Scotty leaned over the console, his heart pounding. "What is it?"

"There's a faint energy field surrounding the ship. It's like nothing we've ever seen before. It's... it's almost like it's alive," Chekov said, his eyes wide with wonder.

Scotty's mind raced. An energy field that was alive? It was preposterous, but so was their current situation. He had to think fast. "If it's alive, maybe we can communicate with it. Try to understand what it wants."

Using the ship's remaining power, Scotty devised a way to send out a signal, a series of pulses designed to mimic basic communication. He held his breath, praying for a response.

The console flickered, and then, incredibly, the ship's systems began to hum back to life. Lights flickered on, consoles powered up, and the familiar thrum of the engines filled the air.

"We did it!" Chekov exclaimed, his face breaking into a wide grin.

Scotty felt a surge of relief and pride. They had done it. They had saved the ship. But more than that, they had discovered something new, something that defied explanation.

As the crew cheered, Scotty allowed himself a rare moment of satisfaction. He had grown, not just as an engineer, but as a leader. And it was all thanks to the trust and support of his crew.

"Chief Engineer's log, supplemental," he said, his voice steady. "Enterprise is back online, thanks to the ingenuity and perseverance of the crew. We've encountered an unknown energy field, one that appears to be sentient. Our journey continues, and with it, our growth and understanding. End log."

As he looked around at his team, Scotty knew that no matter what challenges lay ahead, they would face them together. And that made all the difference.

writing_prompt: When a relentless agent arrives to audit Peter's team, Neal finds himself under suspicion for a forgery he didn’t commit. To clear his name—and protect Peter—he hatches a plan that might just blur the line between clever and reckless.
story:
Neal sat at his desk, the weight of the audit announcement pressing heavily on his shoulders. The news had come in that morning, and the atmosphere in the FBI office had shifted from its usual controlled chaos to something far more tense. Agent Collins, notorious for his relentless pursuit of corruption, was arriving in less than twenty-four hours. Neal could already feel the scrutiny intensifying, and he hadn't even met the man yet.

Peter had tried to reassure him, but Neal knew better. As a former con man turned consultant, he was always under a microscope. And now, with Collins on the scene, any small misstep could spell disaster for him and, by extension, Peter. Neal couldn’t shake the feeling that this audit was more than just routine. 

He leaned back in his chair, staring at the ceiling, his mind racing. He needed a plan—a plan that would clear his name and protect Peter. A plan that would require all his ingenuity and perhaps a little bit of luck. He couldn't let Peter down. Not after everything Peter had done for him.

Later that evening, as the office emptied, Neal wandered over to Peter’s desk. Peter looked up from his paperwork, concern etched on his face. "Neal, you okay?"

Neal forced a smile. "Just thinking about the audit. Collins has a reputation, you know?"

Peter nodded. "I know, but we have nothing to hide. Just stick to the truth."

"The truth," Neal repeated, mulling over the word. "Right."

Peter’s phone rang, breaking the moment. He picked it up, and Neal took the opportunity to slip away, heading toward the conference room. He needed to clear his head, to think without interruptions. Once inside, he pulled out his notebook and began sketching out a plan. 

The next day, Collins arrived promptly at 9 AM, his presence immediately casting a shadow over the office. He was tall, with a sharp gaze that seemed to pierce through anyone who dared to meet it. Neal could feel Collins' eyes on him, assessing, judging. 

The morning passed in a blur of questions and document reviews. Neal answered everything with practiced ease, but he could tell Collins wasn’t convinced. It didn’t help that a forgery had surfaced recently, one that bore striking similarities to Neal’s old work. Neal knew he hadn’t done it, but convincing Collins was another matter.

As lunch approached, Neal found his opportunity. He needed to prove his innocence in a way that would leave no doubt, but it had to be subtle, clever. He approached Peter’s office, knocking lightly before entering.

"Peter, I need to step out for a bit," Neal said. "I have an idea."

Peter raised an eyebrow. "An idea?"

Neal nodded. "Trust me."

Peter hesitated, then nodded. "Be careful."

Neal left the office, making his way to a small art gallery downtown. He had a hunch, and if he was right, this gallery might hold the key to clearing his name. He entered the gallery, his eyes scanning the various pieces on display. 

It didn’t take long to find what he was looking for. A painting, recently acquired, bore the telltale signs of a forgery. The technique was close to his, but not perfect. Neal approached the gallery owner, a woman in her mid-thirties with a keen eye for art.

"Excuse me," Neal said, flashing his most charming smile. "I couldn’t help but notice this piece. Do you have any information on the artist?"

The owner smiled back. "It’s a recent acquisition. The artist goes by the name of S. Taylor. Quite talented, don’t you think?"

"Indeed," Neal replied, his mind working quickly. "I’d love to know more about their other works. Do you have any contact information?"

The owner hesitated but eventually provided a business card. Neal thanked her and left the gallery, dialing the number as soon as he was outside. 

The phone rang several times before a voice answered. "Hello?"

"Mr. Taylor," Neal began, choosing his words carefully. "I’m a big fan of your work. I was wondering if we could meet to discuss a potential commission."

There was a pause, then the voice replied, "Sure. How about the café on 5th street in an hour?"

Neal agreed, ending the call. He had a feeling this meeting would provide the answers he needed.

An hour later, Neal sat across from a man who looked oddly familiar. As they talked, Neal realized this man had once been a minor player in the art forgery world, someone who had admired Neal's work a little too closely. It didn’t take long for Neal to confirm his suspicions. This "S. Taylor" was the forger responsible for the recent piece.

Armed with this knowledge, Neal returned to the FBI office, presenting his findings to Peter and Collins. Collins scrutinized the evidence, his expression unreadable. Finally, he nodded.

"Looks like you were right, Caffrey," Collins said begrudgingly. "You’re off the hook."

Neal sighed in relief, glancing at Peter. They shared a knowing look, the bond of trust between them stronger than ever.
